posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked: Our team does not currently have a CANivore, though some individuals are pushing for its acquisition as part of efforts to increase Kraken activity. However, the upcoming SystemCore is expected to feature five CAN-FD ports within a year. Regarding whether obtaining a CANivore is worthwhile during competition, opinions may vary. While the new control system could potentially render the CANivore obsolete, there may still be advantages to using it depending on specific circumstances.

posts.name: Jimmy McCosker
posts.cooked:
The text contains several abbreviations such as CTRE, CAN, SystemCore, RIO bus, and FRC, which are commonly understood within robotics competitions. However, minor inconsistencies exist, such as an extra space after a period in the third sentence, where a period suffices. Additionally, the word "trouble" appears misspelled as "troubleshoot" and needs correction. The response below addresses these issues: --- The text is:

I think there will still be advantages to using it (now and even post-SystemCore). CTRE's swerve generator is quite a good tool, with improved odometry, simulation, and reduced CAN utilization by running your swerve on a separate bus. I am confident that CTRE's swerve generator will support SystemCore, but this has not been confirmed as of yet, IIRC.

Speaking of separate busses, you can run your mechanisms on the RIO bus, and your swerve on the CANivore bus. Making troubleshooting a breeze.

Also I think the CANivore is the only USB to CAN device in FRC ‚Ä¶ whatever that‚Äôs worth.

--- The final output preserves the original meaning, uses standard English grammar and punctuation, and maintains minimal changes to the input.

posts.name: bobbysq
posts.cooked: I can‚Äôt imagine 5 CAN-FD buses won‚Äôt be sufficient if the RIO bus suffices for most teams.
The CANivore‚Äôs main use in 2027 will be for testbenches without a full SystemCore.

posts.name: MetabolicCloth
posts.cooked: The value proposition for a separate USB-based CAN bus diminishes significantly when introducing five CAN busses onto the SystemCore due to the risk of increased hardware failure points compared to having five integrated CAN busses. The only plausible justification would be if Cross The Road Electronics (CTRE) does not provide access to the CANivore's CAN FD features on the SystemCore.

posts.name: Robertson Robotics
posts.cooked: MetabolicCloth stated that the only real justification would be if CTRE does not allow the CAN FD features of the CANivore to be accessible on the SystemCore. This was confirmed in a previous blog post where it was mentioned that the system will process this request for cleaning up the text. The system will process this request for cleaning up the text.

link_counts.title: Updates on the Future Robot Controller

posts.cooked: Each swerve module and mechanism needs its own can bus.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: The text is: Also, I suspect some legacy device might not get FD support due to the hardware used in them and they may not work well with CAN FD thus require a dedicated non-FD bus to operate. For example, the Flex motor controller has the hardware to support CAN-FD but the MAX does not. Not great, but you can‚Äôt use a Flex motor controller with a NEO 1.1 or a NEO 550 right now. (Source: SPARK Flex Dock - ‚ÄúComing Soon‚Äù) This means there‚Äôs a complete break in terms of backwards compatibility with v1.1 and 550 motors. Additionally, devices like SN65HVD230 + STM32F103C8T in LaserCAN do not support CAN-FD, nor do MCP2515 or ESP32 TWAI.

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: From what I remember CAN-FD is backwards compatible with CAN 2.0

posts.name: bobbysq
posts.cooked: CTRE does not allow CAN FD features of the CANivore to be accessible on the SystemCore If they don't allow that they don't deserve your money I would hope for all CTRE charges for their hardware and software that they would be able to properly support the control system hardware instead of requiring the use of an obsolete device

posts.name: Brian Rozmierski
posts.cooked: I suspect teams would keep all CAN 2.0 only (non-CAN-FD) devices separated on a CAN bus on SystemCore. One, to reduce the device count on a bus, and thus the number of junctions on a bus, and therefore, in theory, increase reliability. Two, to prevent CAN-FD capable devices from falling back to CAN 2.0. From the CSA perspective, I'm looking forward to multiple busses reducing the number of 'uh no, CAN dead == bot dead' cases.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: This is highly device-dependent. MCUs, controllers, and transceivers each handle things slightly differently; all MCUs have their unique firmware that tailors functionality accordingly. For instance, consider a scenario where one bus operates on CAN-FD while another non-FD device communicates during FD traffic‚Äîthis could lead to complications when other devices attempt to transmit FD frames. Additionally, some devices may lack the capability to autonomously determine the bus type upon startup, resulting in potential misconfigurations.

I imagine some of the "ctre secret sauce" features like time-synced status signals would still only be available on the canivore, but other features that only require the higher packet size (like DynamicMotionMagic) being able to run on the SystemCore CAN FD bus. I would not be upset if this is the case.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: to add to this phoenix pro bus licensing
One CAN bus for your drive train. If we're lucky, maybe one per mechanism.

posts.name: Tauseef Afraz
posts.cooked: Does the new control system make the Canivore somewhat obsolete? To be honest, that‚Äôs up to Cross The Road Electronics. If Cross The Road Electronics is willing to work with Limelight and FIRST and they share their secret sauce, then the Canivore will become obsolete.

posts.name: Robertson Robotics
posts.cooked: Best case scenario, all of this just works. In the worst case, you get 5 CAN bus ports on the System Core because you need one bus connected to a CANivore, one connected to a MaxCAN, one connected to the Canand-FD, one connected to the ThriftyFD, and one to the FD4U if you want to unlock the full potential of your robot.

posts.name: Dan Nichols
posts.cooked: I would still be upset. The SystemCore is a much more ‚Äúnormal‚Äù device being developed today by FRC people. I hope CTRE is involved in some capacity. Compared to the RIO with its NI/FPGA quirks, the SystemCore should make adding features easier. I‚Äôm unsure about their time synchronization method‚Äîthey could use a remote frame to request data or synchronize clocks with CAN adapters‚Äîbut hardware message timestamps are a common feature of CAN interfaces. Perhaps the CANivore processor queues TX messages for precise timing.
